verses.text: After the Sabbath, at dawn on the first day of the week, Mary Magdalene and the other Mary went to see the tomb.
verses.comment: Matthew highlights that the resurrection occurs on the first day of the week, a detail also seen in other Gospels. The presence of both Marys provides eyewitness testimony. The change from Sabbath to Sunday hints at a new beginning—later, Sunday becomes known as 'the Lord’s Day.'

verses.text: Suddenly, there was a great earthquake; for an angel of the Lord descended from heaven, came and rolled back the stone, and sat on it.
verses.comment: The earthquake emphasizes divine intervention, echoing biblical moments when God’s power is made visible. The angel's action indicates God's authority over the barriers to the resurrection.

verses.text: His appearance was like lightning, and his clothing was white as snow.
verses.comment: Angelic glory signifies a heavenly messenger; light and white garments symbolize purity and holiness, frequently seen in visions of divine beings in Scripture.

verses.text: And out of fear of him the guards trembled and became like dead men.
verses.comment: Human power is rendered powerless before God's messengers. The Roman guards, symbols of earthly authority, are incapacitated, highlighting the superiority of divine power.

verses.text: But the angel said to the women, 'Do not be afraid. For I know you are looking for Jesus, who was crucified.'
verses.comment: The angel reassures the faithful while the unbelieving are stricken with fear, illustrating a common biblical theme of comfort given to those who seek the Lord.

verses.text: 'He is not here, for he has risen, just as he said. Come, see the place where he lay.'
verses.comment: The resurrection fulfills Jesus’ prior prophecy and Old Testament promises (see Psalm 16:10). The invitation to 'see' the empty tomb authenticates the reality of the resurrection.

verses.text: 'Then go quickly and tell his disciples that he has risen from the dead, and look, he is going ahead of you into Galilee; there you will see him. Behold, I have told you.'
verses.comment: The angel sends the women as the first witnesses, a noteworthy elevation of their role. Jesus’ appearance in Galilee strengthens the universal calling of the disciples—a foreshadowing of their apostolic mission.

verses.text: So they left the tomb quickly, with fear and great joy, and ran to tell his disciples.
verses.comment: Their mixture of fear and joy shows an authentic response to the holy. The urgency to share the news parallels the call all Christians receive to spread the Gospel.

verses.text: And behold, Jesus met them and said, 'Greetings!' They came up, took hold of his feet, and worshiped him.
verses.comment: The women worship Jesus, demonstrating his divine status. Early Christian worship was reserved for God alone, making this a clear hint of Jesus’ deity (cf. Psalm 97:7).

verses.text: Then Jesus said to them, 'Do not be afraid; go and tell my brothers to go to Galilee, and there they will see me.'
verses.comment: Jesus calls the disciples 'brothers,' showing an intimate connection to those entrusted with his mission. Gathering in Galilee anticipates a moment of commissioning and unity.

verses.text: While they were on their way, some of the guards went into the city and reported to the chief priests everything that had happened.
verses.comment: The guards, who had witnessed the supernatural events, report to the religious leaders—showing a contrast between honest witness and how authority might react to truth.

verses.text: After the chief priests had assembled with the elders, they devised a plan and gave a large sum of money to the soldiers,
verses.comment: The religious leaders’ scheme demonstrates a stubborn rejection of God’s plan, preferring deception over faith—echoing previous plots against Jesus.

verses.text: 'Say, “His disciples came by night and stole him away while we were asleep.”'
verses.comment: The authorities attempt to undermine the resurrection with dishonesty. This reflects the ongoing battle between truth and falsehood in the world and in history.

verses.text: And if this comes to the governor’s ears, we will satisfy him and keep you out of trouble.'
verses.comment: A political move offering protection for complicity in falsehood, showing the corrupt nature of the world’s powers when confronted with divine truth.

verses.text: So they took the money and did as they were instructed. And this story has been spread among the Jews to this day.
verses.comment: The perpetuation of the false story highlights the durability of opposition to the resurrection, even as eyewitness testimony gave birth to the Church’s mission.

verses.text: But the eleven disciples went to Galilee, to the mountain where Jesus had directed them.
verses.comment: Mountains in Scripture often signal important encounters with God. The obedience of the eleven signifies unity, mission, and the foundation of Christ’s Church.

verses.text: When they saw him, they worshiped him; but some doubted.
verses.comment: Worship is again offered to Jesus, reinforcing his divinity. The mention of doubt acknowledges the reality of faith’s journey and the transformation that occurs in encounter with the risen Lord.

verses.text: Then Jesus came to them and said, 'All authority in heaven and on earth has been given to me.'
verses.comment: Jesus explicitly claims divine authority, fulfilling Daniel 7:14 and Psalm 2:8. This universal lordship is foundational—Christ is both God and King, sovereign over all creation.

verses.text: 'Go therefore and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Spirit,'
verses.comment: This commission establishes the universal mission of the Church and formalizes Trinitarian baptism. The explicit reference to Father, Son, and Holy Spirit is a key moment in Trinitarian theology, revealing the unity and mystery of God.

verses.text: 'teaching them to keep everything I have commanded you. And behold, I am with you always, even to the end of the age.'
verses.comment: Jesus commands not only faith, but obedience to all his teachings—implying continuity and authority. His promise to remain present with his followers, like God’s assurance to Moses, points to the spiritual and sacramental presence of Christ through his Church until the end of time.
